title: 2.1: Emitter Shapes
summary: Explore various emitter shapes: cone, sphere, box, and more
intro: In this lesson, you'll learn about different emitter shapes available in the Node Particle Editor. Each shape creates particles from a different volume, giving you control over where particles spawn. We'll focus on Cone Shape block, which creates directional effects like fire or fountains, and understand its properties like radius, angle, radiusRange, and heightRange.
steps: Create a <filter-value>System</filter-value> block - this is the root of your particle system
Add a <filter-value>Texture</filter-value> block to provide a texture for the particles and connect to System block
Load a <textures>flare.png</textures> by load button in the Texture block properties
Add a <filter-value>CreateParticle</filter-value> block to emit particles and connect to System block
Add a <filter-value>Color4</filter-value> block and set its value to a base color
Connect the Color4 block's output to CreateParticle block's color input
Add a <filter-value>Float</filter-value> block and set its value for base size
Connect the Float block's output to CreateParticle block's size input
Add a <filter-value>ConeShape</filter-value> block to emit particles in a cone pattern and connect between CreateParticle and System blocks
Add a <filter-value>Float</filter-value> block and set its value for cone radius (base width of the cone)
Connect the Float block's output to ConeShape block's radius input
Add another <filter-value>Float</filter-value> block and set its value for cone angle (opening angle in radians)
Connect the Float block's output to ConeShape block's angle input
Add another <filter-value>Float</filter-value> block and set its value for radiusRange (random variation in radius, range: 0-1)
Connect the Float block's output to ConeShape block's radiusRange input
Add another <filter-value>Float</filter-value> block and set its value for heightRange (random variation in height, range: 0-1)
Connect the Float block's output to ConeShape block's heightRange input
Add an <filter-value>UpdatePosition</filter-value> block to handle particle movement and connect between ConeShape and System blocks
Add a <filter-value>Position</filter-value> block and a <filter-value>ScaledDirection</filter-value> block
Add a math <filter-value>Add</filter-value> block to combine position and direction
Connect the result to UpdatePosition block's position input
Experiment with different radius and angle values to see how they affect particle distribution
Note: Other shapes like <filter-value>SphereShape</filter-value>, <filter-value>CylinderShape</filter-value>, and <filter-value>BoxShape</filter-value> are also available

blocks.name: Sphere Shape Block
blocks.description: Emits particles from a sphere shape. Particles spawn within the sphere volume, with control over radius and distribution. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and configure its properties in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Name
properties.description: The display name of the emitter. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

properties.name: Radius
properties.description: The radius of the sphere. Larger values create a bigger emission area. Connect a Float block to this input.

properties.name: Radius Range
properties.description: Controls where particles spawn within the sphere. 0 = center only, 1 = anywhere in the sphere. Connect a Float block to this input.

properties.name: Direction Randomizer
properties.description: Controls the randomness of particle direction. 0 = uniform direction, 1 = completely random. Connect a Float block to this input.

blocks.name: Box Shape Block
blocks.description: Emits particles from a box/cube shape. Particles spawn within the box volume defined by width, height, and depth. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and configure its properties in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Name
properties.description: The display name of the emitter. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

blocks.name: Cone Shape Block
blocks.description: Emits particles from a cone shape. Useful for creating directional effects like fire, smoke, or fountains. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and configure its properties in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Name
properties.description: The display name of the emitter. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

properties.name: Radius
properties.description: The base radius of the cone. Connect a Float block to this input.

properties.name: Angle
properties.description: The angle of the cone in radians. Connect a Float block to this input.

blocks.name: Cylinder Shape Block
blocks.description: Emits particles from a cylinder shape. Particles spawn within the cylindrical volume. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and configure its properties in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Name
properties.description: The display name of the emitter. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

properties.name: Radius
properties.description: The radius of the cylinder. Connect a Float block to this input.

properties.name: Height
properties.description: The height of the cylinder. Connect a Float block to this input.

blocks.name: Box Shape Block (Alternative)
blocks.description: For concentrated effects, you can use Box Shape block with very small dimensions. All particles spawn from a small area, useful for concentrated effects. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and configure its properties in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Name
properties.description: The display name of the emitter. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

codeCopy: Different emitter shapes give you control over the spatial distribution of particles. Sphere Shape block creates particles within a spherical volume, while Box Shape block uses a rectangular volume. Each shape has specific properties like radius, height, or angle that control the emission area. The radiusRange property in Sphere Shape block is particularly useful - it lets you control whether particles spawn only at the center (0) or throughout the entire volume (1).
objectives: Understand different emitter shapes and their properties
Learn how to control particle spawn distribution with radiusRange
Use directionRandomizer to control emission direction
Understand when to use each shape type (Box, Sphere, Cone, Cylinder)
Configure shape properties like radius, angle, and height in the properties panel

commonMistakes.explanation: radiusRange controls where particles spawn within a shape. 0 means particles spawn only at the center, 1 means anywhere in the volume. Using wrong values creates unexpected distributions.
commonMistakes.solution: Use radiusRange = 0 for concentrated emission (center only), radiusRange = 1 for full volume emission. For sphere shapes, this is particularly important for controlling particle spread.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using wrong shape for the desired effect
commonMistakes.explanation: Each shape has specific use cases. Using Box Shape block for a fountain effect or Cone Shape block for uniform distribution won't give the desired result.
commonMistakes.solution: Use Box Shape block with small dimensions for concentrated effects, Sphere Shape block for radial effects, Cone Shape block for directional effects (fire, fountains), Box Shape block for rectangular areas, Cylinder Shape block for cylindrical volumes.

commonMistakes.explanation: Shapes have properties like radius, angle, height that must be set correctly. Using default values or wrong types causes incorrect emission.
commonMistakes.solution: Always set shape properties explicitly. For Cone Shape block, connect Float blocks to both radius and angle inputs. For Sphere Shape block, connect Float blocks to radius and radiusRange inputs. Configure these in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

homework: Try changing the sphere radius to see how it affects particle distribution
Experiment with radiusRange values between 0 and 1
Replace Sphere Shape block with Cone Shape block and adjust the angle
Create a particle system using Cylinder Shape block
Compare the visual difference between Box Shape block with small dimensions and Sphere Shape block with radiusRange = 0
